Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Name.subject: Gilbert, Tess, $d b. 1904 or 1905
Type.genre: Black-and-white photographs|~|film stills|~|Portrait photographs|~|cellulose nitrate film
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Tess Gilbert does not appear in the AFI catalog. However, she refers to herself as a screen actress in "My Beauty Hint," The Reading Eagle, 22 Feb. 1933: 9; and she is identified, in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle 12 Apr. 1936: 43, as a "script girl" for the Capra film "Ladies of Leisure" (1930), produced by Columbia Pictures. She referred to herself as a script writer for the 1930 Census, which lists her place of birth as Russia.
Title: Tess Gilbert, script assistant, circa 1933
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Tess Gilbert [crossed out:] script. Portraits G.

Description.note: Charlie Murray and George Sidney starred in films together in the 1920's and 1930's. They appeared in one full-length film produced by Columbia Pictures: Around the Corner (1930), as well as six comic shorts produced by Columbia Pictures and released in 1934.
Title: Grocery store set for Charlie Murray and George Sidney film, circa 1930-1934
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Summary: Text from negative enclosure: Charlie Murray. George Sidney.
Description.longitude: The set includes produce, canned goods (Borden's evaporated milk, Willapoint oysters, Monarch grapes, S and W asparagus and salmon), boxes (Lipton's tea, Baby Ruth candy bars, Campbell's soup), and Cudahy's puritan ham and bacon. There is a potbelly stove at the center and there are posters on the walls for Royal gelatin and baking powder, and Mail Pouch tobacco.

Project Name: Columbia Pictures Stills and Key books
Type.genre: Black-and-white photographs|~|film stills|~|cellulose nitrate film
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: The set includes a counter with a scale on it, as well as shelves filled with food (Borden's evaporated milk, Karo, Willapoint oysters, S and W baked beans, Campbell's pork and beans, Cudahy's spiced corned beef, Morton's salt), with boxes of Morton's salt, Kennel King dog food, and Sunlight eggs piled in front of the shelves.|~|Charlie Murray and George Sidney starred in films together in the 1920's and 1930's. They appeared in one full-length film produced by Columbia Pictures: Around the Corner (1930), as well as six comic shorts produced by Columbia Pictures and released in 1934.
Title: Grocery store set for Charlie Murray and George Sidney film, circa 1930-1934

Description.note: Film still from the Columbia Pictures musical comedy All Ashore (1953). Featured at center are singer Dick Haymes (at left) and dancer/actor Ray McDonald. Description.note: Photograph of actor Porter Hall (who portrayed Lazarus Ward) on the set of the  western film Arizona (1940). Hall is photographed in costume - wearing a hat, overcoat, and vest with watch chain visible, and a gun belt around his waist (gun in holster) - stands next to a cactus as he drinks from a small Southwestern basketry dish with stepped design. Drops of water are seen trickling from the woven dish. A ramada (an open air shelter made of thatch and branches) stands directly next to the cactus, providing shade for the actor as well as a second man (wearing a short sleeved shirt and helmet imprinted with a red cross) seen in the background.|~|The Columbia Pictures production was filmed on location in Arizona.
Title: Porter Hall drinking from a basketry dish on the set of Arizona, circa 1940

Description.note: The Brave Bulls was shot at Columbia Studios and on location in Mexico City, spring of 1950. The film was released in 1951.|~|A bullfighter - the matador - captured as he is being handed a blade by a "sword page" (mozo de espadas). The matador wears traditional attire, including a montera hat, short embroidered jacket (chaquetilla), and close-fitting pants. The photograph captures the matador just as he is throwing his cape a wooden barrier. In the background is an additional bullfighter holding a cape. Signs along the arena stands read: Stetson, Nieto Regalos, Stetson, Gayosso, Madero  The arena is possibly the Plaza de Toros in Mexico City.
Title: Mel Ferrer as matador Lus Bello in The Brave Bulls, 1951
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Subject.descriptiveTopic: Bowling alleys $ California $ Los Angeles|~|Bowlers $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Probably photographed at the Sunset Bowling Center, located on the Old Warner Brothers Studio lot along Sunset Boulevard (now Sunset Bronson Studios). Text etched into the bowling balls: "Property of S.B.C." The facility is noted in the Los Angeles Times as being a location for bowling tournaments, most notably between film studios, dates spanning 1939-1951.
Title: Columbia Pictures bowling team, Los Angeles, 1940s
